item.title: Neither self nor this: Receivers in Go
item.description: Neither self nor this: Receivers in Go When getting started with Go, there is a strong temptation to bring baggage from your previous language. It‚Äôs a heuristic which is usually helpful, but sometimes counter-productive and inevitably results in regret. Go does not have classes and objects, but it does have types that we can make many instances of. item.description: The goal of designing a public API response layout is to balance ease of use for consumers with commitment of stability from the provider. item.title: Urllib3, Stripe, and Open Source Grants
item.description: Urllib3, Stripe, and Open Source Grants Helping the future come a little soonerSix years ago, I built a better Python http library. It had then-novel things like connection pooling, thread-safety, multipart encoding, and more. Today, every Python user depends on it. Maintaining something for six years on my own time is not easy, even with a slew of coping strategies. A few hours here and there, every week, and slowly it chugs along‚Äîlargely thanks to contributors undertaking the bigger tasks that I can‚Äôt knock off in a quick afternoon.

item.description: Laser Eye Surgery “What was it like?” More than anything else, it was creepy. … But worth it. item.title: Password Management Utilities
item.description: Password Management Utilities We live in a time when cleartext usernames and passwords are leaked on a daily basis. In the last couple of months my accounts got compromised on Gawker, Sony, and MtGox. I decided it’s time to start using the one-password-per-service technique. These are tools I found in my research. I’m currently using SuperGenPass, but considering writing my own version that uses customizeable multipass sha512, more symbol breadth in passwords, and some other improvements.

item.title: Arbitrarily-Structured Data in Relational Databases
item.description: Arbitrarily-Structured Data in Relational Databases This approach is similar to FriendFeed’s schemaless database framework. The key difference is in the data locality. The goal is not to build an effective schemaless database on top of a relational database, but rather to accomodate for rapidly-evolving relational schemas and reducing the difficult of migrating forward. Hypothesis In an evolving relational (SQL) database schema, we store two types of data: Data we will be querying against and data we will be displaying.

item.title: Rules of thumb for novice designers (like myself)
item.description: Rules of thumb for novice designers (like myself) My strategy as a novice designer is to keep track of some rules of thumb to reduce the probability of making bad mistakes from lack of experience.
